children.subject: <md>Ive never had my transcript checked for an internship and the background check that was just run for my full-time job only checked enrollment status. I wouldn't worry about it.</md>

history.content:
I wouldn't worry about it. In a majority of cases your transcript will not even be requested, and when it is, they will probably not scrutinize it but rather verify your enrollment status/major/GPA etc. since they would ask for it later in the application process (I pretty much never had to submit a transcript for a position for which I wasn't at least interviewed). Many companies, especially highly sought-after ones, probably do not even have time to look at everyone's transcripts. I could only imagine it mattering if the position were highly specialized with few applicants, but for most people, if they p/np'ed a course, will probably not specialize in that subject anyway.

EDIT: realized after Prof. Weaver's comment below that I forgot to mention that the above is just for your question about tech companies--grad school is a different story and if that is a part of your decision, then I would consider keeping the graded option (that's why I'm still doing graded, in any case). So long as you get a pretty good grade it will still look better than a P, which is a bit dubious.

I wouldn't worry about it. In a majority of cases your transcript will not even be requested, and when it is, they will probably not scrutinize it but rather verify your enrollment status/major/GPA etc. since they would ask for it later in the application process (I pretty much never had to submit a transcript for a position for which I wasn't at least interviewed). Many companies, especially highly sought-after ones, probably do not even have time to look at everyone's transcripts. I could only imagine it mattering if the position were highly specialized with few applicants, but for most people, if they p/np'ed a course, will probably not specialize in that subject anyway.

children.subject:
I'd worry about it LESS for a company than grad school. I've hardly ever heard of GPA mattering.

For grad school, spring was a wash.  But for fall, I could see some treating a P as a B, because it isn't P/NP, but A/P/NP and they know it.

I interview people (specifically new college grads) as part of my job and have a gist of how recruiting works where I work. Overall GPA may be looked at, but not how that GPA came to be, including what classes were PNP'd.

I assume things would be similar for other companies since it's a practicality issue above all. Having some sort of automated screening factor this in is overly complicated and unnecessary. Once a candidate is brought in for an interview, interviewers get a host of other information that could help make an informed decision that whether a course is PNP'd is largely irrelevant.

history.content: From what I saw, it would not negatively impact my admission to grad school. For those of you who talked to the tech companies about the P/NP policy, do you know if that would impact my chances of getting a job at a tech company?
history.subject: P/NP impact for a job at a tech company
